titleStmt.title: Iohn White's defence. In the behalfe of himself, his honoured commander, the lieutenant of the Tower and the other his fellow warders. Against a lying and slanderous pamphlet written by Iohn Lilburne, and intitled Liberty vindicated against slavery. The author of which pamphlet, is here reprehended for his slandering, taxed for his libelling, and incited (the spirit of disaffection abandoned.) to submit himselfe to his rulers, [brace] as he is commanded. To live in unity with his fellow commanders, [brace] as he ought.
titleStmt.author: White, John, warder of the Tower.

titleStmt.title: Iohn White's defence. In the behalfe of himself, his honoured commander, the lieutenant of the Tower and the other his fellow warders. Against a lying and slanderous pamphlet written by Iohn Lilburne, and intitled Liberty vindicated against slavery. The author of which pamphlet, is here reprehended for his slandering, taxed for his libelling, and incited (the spirit of disaffection abandoned.) to submit himselfe to his rulers, [brace] as he is commanded. To live in unity with his fellow commanders, [brace] as he ought.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: IOHN WHITE'S DEFENCE. In the behalfe of him≈øelf, his honoured Commander, the Lieutenant of the Tower and the other his Fellow Warders.
Again≈øt a lying and ≈ølanderous Pamphlet written by Iohn Lilburne, and intitled Liberty vindicated again≈øt Slavery.
The Author of which Pamphlet, is here reprehended for his ≈ølandering, taxed for his Libelling, and incited the ≈øpirit of di≈øaffection abandoned.)
To ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to his Rulers, As he is Commanded.
To live in unity with his fellow Commanders, As he ought.

q.p: There be ≈øix things doth the Lord hate, yea, ≈øeven is an abomination unto him.
A proud looke, a lying tongue, and hands that ≈øhed Innocent blood.
A heart that devi≈øeth wicked abominations. Feet that be ≈øwift in running to doe mi≈øchiefe.
A fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe that ≈øpeaketh lies, and he that ≈øoweth di≈øcord among≈øt brethren

div.p: LONDON, Printed by E. G. for JOHN HARDESTY at the Signe of the Black ≈øpread-Eagle in Duck-Lane, 1646.

div.head: To the Intelligent Reader.
div.p: AS we are not bound to reveale all truths, ≈øo are we tyed to vindicate the truth being evill ≈øpoken of. Lieutenant Colonel Lilburne, a man who≈øe folly the world talketh of, who≈øe pre≈øumption all men admire, and who≈øe wrethed E≈øtate, as being a man given up to him≈øelfe, all men ought to deplore, having Taxed, Defamed, and De≈øpi≈øed even the Governors and Rulers of this Nation, may cau≈øe tho≈øe that are inferiors the le≈ø≈øe to ≈øet by, and ≈ølight his Calumnies.

But fora≈ømuch as tho≈øe Powers have already begun, and at their plea≈øure, may proceed to puni≈øh his ≈øawcine≈ø≈øe, which priviledge, I and others of the Commons want: is therefore remaines that we may a≈ø≈øume that liberty, as by writing and ≈øpeaking to vindicate our ≈øelves.

Fir≈øt, therefore fora≈ømuch as in a Pamphlet lately Printed, he particularly enveigheth again≈øt me fal≈øely, taxing me of that wherof I am not the lea≈øt guilty, I thought good gentle Reader, in the behalfe of my ≈øelfe, my Lieutenant and other my Fellow wardens of the Tower unworthily by him calumniated, to publi≈øh this my An≈øwer, which the Highe≈øt knowes to be truth, and nothing but the truth, which followes.

Fir≈øt, he cryeth out and bitterly exclaimeth of the great Fees, which the Lieutenant of the Tower, and the Gentle-man Porter extort; let therefore all men Judge, what rea≈øon he hath to ≈øay ≈øo, when as they never received any of him, nor ever demanded any,
and here let me di≈øcharge my con≈øcience freely; I prote≈øt not out of favour or affection, but out of the intire love I beare to the worth of the party,Who adventured his life for the Parliament at the ‚Ä¢ eleife of Gloce≈øter. I conceive there was never a more pious upright and wel-affected man Lieutenant of the Tower, then he that executeth that office at the pre≈øent, one for whom we have cau≈øe to ble≈ø≈øe God, and acknowledge our thankfulne≈ø≈øe to the Parliament and City for their care for their chu≈øing of ≈øo accompli≈øht a man as he is, to execute that Office of ≈øo high a concernment; the Gentleman Porter al≈øo an upright man, for ought ever I could perceive, who have been an eye witne≈ø≈øe of his Actions; but Lilburnes carriage and calumnyes are ≈øuch, that ≈øome of his be≈øt friends begin to de≈øert him, ≈øome of them have ≈øaid to me, that they were ≈øorty to ≈øee his unworthy carriage and behaviour; how ba≈øely hath this man Lilburne abu≈øed and vilified the ever to be honoured Earle of Manche≈øter, who hath ventured his life, and ≈ølighted his Estate, to advance the publike good? and indeed who is there truly vertuous, that hath not ta≈øted of his ≈ølanders? but who≈øoever ≈øhapeth not him≈øelfe to his cut, and walketh not in the ≈øame path of error that he doth; by him is accur≈øed; and not onely he, but al≈øo all his complices with their new lights placed in darke Lanthornes, mi≈øguide them≈øelves, and deceive others, and refu≈øe all fellow≈øhip ≈øave with their Brethren in‚Äî but now to the matter intended.
The Pamphleter ≈øaith,

One White a Warder of the Tower,1 Complaint. who came to the Lieutenant Colonel in Newgate, and gave him their evill and provoking Language, doth with contumelious, and reproachfull words, and ge≈øtures, frequently affront and abu≈øe, &c.

Here ob≈øerve he taxeth me once to have vi≈øited him in Newgate, and there to have given him evill and provoking Language; what my words were he reciteth not, but I ≈øhall; with the rea≈øon why I went to vi≈øit him having formerly ≈øome acquaintance with him, when he was an Apprentice, with a Cloth-Drawer; I then being a Clothier in Reading had occa≈øion to have much Cloth pa≈ø≈øe through his Ma≈øters hands, and ≈øome time after hearing of his being Pri≈øoner in Newgate, I went to ≈øee him there, and being admitted into his chamber, I found him writing of a Letter, one ≈øtanding by him to receive it; when he had fini≈øh't, he asked me, if
I had any thing to him; I told him, I came out of my love to ≈øee him, and de≈øired him for the glory of God,Fooles de≈øpi≈øe Coun≈øell ≈øaith Solomon. to carry him≈øelfe humbly, and as one po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the ≈øpirit, as onely profe≈ø≈øing the Go≈øpell, for if he had a good cau≈øe he would ≈øpoile it in the handling; here he abruptly asked me, if this were all I came for, and rudely pulling me by the Coat ≈øaid, if I had not beene an old man, he would have throwne me downe Stayrs; his rough ≈øpeeches and ≈øturdy ge≈øtures gave me cau≈øe to feare he would doe as he had ≈øaid; being downe the Stayrs I told him, I had heard much of him, now had ≈øeen, and if warine≈ø≈øe prevented not, ≈øpirituall pride would be his overthrow: which he hearing was coming down the Staires after me, but I fled away and e≈øcaped his hands, and this was all the evill and provoking Language which I then gave him. I appeale to all the Pri≈øoners in the Tower, how I have carryed my ≈øelf to him; I wi≈øh Ma≈øter Lilburne no more ill then mine own ≈øoule, I hate not the man, but his manners; and therefore let all the world judge, what cau≈øe this man hath to exclaime of my ill u≈øage of Him.

The ≈øecond Complaint. His next complaint is, that I have oft affronted him in the Tower, and given him reproachfull words. I know none that ever J gave him except once, when upon his commitment to the Tower, he came to the Lieutenants hou≈øe, A ≈øoft an≈øwer turneth away wrath, but fooles are implacable. I came and bowing to him with my Hat in my hand * ≈øaid Ma≈øter Lilburne, I am ≈øorry to ≈øee you come hither in this manner, J pray God help you and give you grace to demeane your ≈øelf in all things as becometh his Child; upon which in a rough manner, he bade me go further from him, he needed not my Prayers or company, at which many of his friends that ≈øtood by ≈øaid they were ≈øorry for his aver≈øene≈ø≈øe, ≈øince which time, I have not had the lea≈øt conference with him.

p.hi: He thirdly, complaineth that on my waiting Day, J keepe back tho≈øe that would come unto him, and doe affront them to this I an≈øwer.

div.p:
When I did vi≈øite, I never kept back any that would come unto him, provided they would give me their names,An≈øwer. and the place of their dwelling; now there have come many that denyed to di≈øcover their names, and where they dwelt, but u≈øed threatnings, and contumelious ≈øpeeches, ≈øaying that we ≈øhould An≈øwer the prohibition of them from going to vi≈øit Colonell Lilburne, and that the time was at hand, when they would come in whether our Lieutenant would or no; now tho≈øe that would di≈øcover their
names, and abode, had free entrance at all times; divers we have proved, who under pretence of going to the Mint, have gone to the chamber of that Coyner of Lyes Lilburne; as for In≈øtance, there came one in a Coach, I asking him whether he would goe, he ≈øaid, to my fellow Frankling; I asked him, if he went to no place el≈øe, he ≈øaid no; I mi≈øtru≈øting his fal≈øhood, ≈øent one of my fellowes after him, who found him inquiring for Lilburns Chamber; my fellow approaching to him, told him he did not aske for Lilburne, but for Frankling when he came in, and brought him back with him to me. I told him he did ill in celling an untruth, to aske for one place and goe to another; yet notwith≈øtanding if he would write downe his name, and his dwelling, &c. herewith the Gentleman, grew greatly inraged, and fured as one had been mad, and threatned me and my fellowes very ≈øeverely, that he would make us dearely An≈øwer, &c. and to ≈øay truth, there repaires not to Lilburne, any one of note ≈øave two or three, but often mens wives, and wa≈øte-coat mayds, and ≈øome ≈øtragling Souldiers; and tho≈øe that come from him, report that he doth not want for money nor wine, now let all men judge, I doing nothing but what I am commanded to doe, and what I mu≈øt doe at my perill, what cau≈øe this defamer hath to complaine of me? which when I con≈øider, as al≈øo his ≈øtandering of others without all ground, I cannot but conclude he hath the Frenzie, and his wits the i≈ø≈øue of a di≈øtemper'd braine, but as long as he per≈øi≈øeth in tho≈øeAmbition, Pride. two Capitall ≈øinnes, the one the overthrow of the Mother of us all E∆≤E, the other, the damning of that once glorious Angell Lucifer, I cannot conceive how hee ≈øhould ≈øhake of tho≈øe bonds of ob≈øtinacy, and malevolencit, or breake tho≈øe yoakes, of malice and revenge wherewith he is fettered, and pinnion'd. For mine own part, let Ma≈øter Lilburns and his complices know, I lo≈øt more for adhering as I ought to the Parliamene then ever he was worth; my ≈øonnes having beene in the States Service, ever ≈øince the beginning of the≈øe warres, under Lord
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and with him in all his Fights, and ≈øince his Re≈øignation under the truly Noble Sir Thomas Fairefax, and with him in all „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , one being a Captain under him, in his own Regiment, who is now Governour of Wallingford, the other Enngne in the ≈øame Regiment; yet I doe not blow a Trumpet nor proclaime what hath been done. His complices, what ever they put forthy, O how
often doe they iterate, and ≈øet downe in Letters Capitall, the worthy ≈øufferer for his Country, LIEVTENANT COLONELL LILBVRNE, as if the Titles of the party could expiate his crimes, whereas it is rather an aggravation thereof and according to the Poet,

q.l: Great is the crime it cannot chu≈øe,
If he be great that doth it u≈øe.

div.p: Sathans Policy.But this I have ob≈øerved in my time, that who ever hath undertaken to maintain, any error or here≈øie, * the devill hath ≈øtill furni≈øhed his minde with arguments to wre≈øtle with all oppo≈øers, nay, and ≈øo farre to prevaile, that in outward e≈øteem, ≈øometimes the DEVILS SOPHISTRY hath triumphed ore the CHRISTIAN VERITY for my part I e≈øteem it my chiefe glory, my con≈øcience bearing me witne≈ø≈øe, that I am to number my ≈øelfe with tho≈øe ≈øolid Citizens, and with them who ≈øay in the Poet;

q.l: We are no Partners with tho≈øe Factious fellowes,
Who bring the fewell, or who blow the bellowes
Of civill di≈øcords, nor ofTime-Servers. tho≈øe that varie
Their principles, when their de≈øignes mi≈øcarrie,
Nor ofThat ty ‚Ä¢ their faith on others, and will beleeve as did their fore-fathers. their Creed who will beleeve no more
Then what they have beleeved heretofore.
Or what their Grand≈øires did beleeve of old,
Or what ≈øhall by their Prie≈øts to them be told;
Nor are we of their minde who therefore doe
WhatOb≈øtinate and blinded Per≈øons. they have done, becau≈øe they have done ≈øo;
But we are men who good advi≈øement had,
Of what we doe, though ≈øome yet thinke us mad;
Men that have all our be≈øt endevours vowd,
ToTrue Chri≈øtians. loo≈øe no freedom, rea≈øon hath allow'd
Men who re≈øolve to ≈øeeke a perfect way,
To walk it as uprightly as we may,
To keepe unchanged, God's and Natures Lawes:
And change all other things, as there is cau≈øe.

div.p: I would de≈øire Ma≈øter Lilburne to remember the Fate of BROVNE, an ob≈øtinate Heretick in the dayes of Queene Elizabeth, and the Father of that ≈øtubborne Sect, the Browni≈øts. And as from Reverend Calvin, the maintainers of his righteous Tenets were called Calvini≈øts, ≈øo from mi≈øled Browne, the confirmers of his wicked tenets were called Browni≈øts; this Brown. the giddy multitude followed in heapes, to heare him preach the Doctrine of Sedition and Rebellion; this man, Ma≈øter Lilburne zealou≈øly imitares, and once like him on Tower Hill, was ≈øurrounded with a company of mechanicks, who at the Con≈øtables approach he exhorts to ≈øtand on their defence, and to kill the Con≈øtable; and about to draw his ≈øword, the Con≈øtable clo≈øed in with him and with-held him, and pre≈øently di≈øarming him, his Audience being di≈øper≈øed, brought him guarded to the Lieutenant of the Tower, who u≈øed him with all lenity, farre better then he de≈øerved: He, by who≈øe favour I know not, e≈øcaping without the payment of five pound due by the Law of our Land, and to be paid by him that ≈øhall dare to affront or hinder a Con≈øtable in the pro≈øecution of his Office. But I now proceed to An≈øwer his fourth Complaint, wherein he averreth, that great and extraordinary Rents are taken for Chambers, whereby I conceive he hoped to in≈øinuate, and according to the proverbe, to curry favour with ≈øome of the Gentlemen in the Tower; but they are ≈øo well acquainted with his Lyes, that they know this is not the fir≈øt.

The fourth Complaint. This medler and bu≈øie body in other mens matters, without all ground, or the lea≈øt rea≈øon on his part, complaineth, and fal≈øely accu≈øeth ≈øome of the warders to take of ≈øome fifty ≈øhillings, of other fourty, of ≈øome thirty, &c. as notorious a Lie, as the Father of Lyes could have belched; true it is, that ≈øome of the Warders have beene ≈øo much a weeke the wor≈øe for ≈øome of their Pri≈øoners; but there is no warder but is well content to take tenne ≈øhillings a weeke for his Chamber, with all furniture belonging to it, neither is any man compelled to give any more then what he li≈øteth but ≈øay we did take more, accounting al≈øo the great care and paines we take ≈øo watch and ward all the yeare long, day and night, for 14. pence a day, and of that we are behinde on Arrears almo≈øt five yeares, ≈øome of us haveing nothing el≈øe in the world to live on, but the Honourable Committee have taken Order for our better payment for the future; I would intreat Ma≈øter Lilburne not to adde to the wickedne≈ø≈øe of his friend, Ma≈øter B.
who hath already ≈øufficiently wronged the warders; and although it plea≈øed his friend aforementioned to ≈øay, that there were not above two or three in all the company that could be tru≈øted without ≈øcruple, yet it cannot be proved, that ever any one of them failed in his tru≈øt, or let e≈øcape any Pri≈øoner during this dangerous time: And here let the Reader take notice, of the wavering, and un≈øtable minde of my accu≈øer; who in this Booke highly advanceth (Magna Charta) and yet in another ≈øtanderous lying Libell, intituled An ALARVM to the hou≈øe of LORDS, he tearmeth it a beggerly Law; and ≈øaith al≈øo that the Laws were made by Kings, to keepe men in ≈ølavery‚Äî and yet the Lord Strafford, and the Archhi≈øhop of Canterbury lo≈øt their heads, for going about to alter them,‚Äî and in a Booke of his intituled, The Freemans Freedome vindicated, page 11. He raileth again≈øt all Power and Authority: what≈øoever, and ≈øetteth up an ab≈øolute Anarchie. His words are the≈øe.

div.head: A POSTSCRIPT, Containing a Generall Propo≈øition.

q.p:
GOd the ab≈øolute Soveraigne Lord and King of things in heaven, and earth; the originall Fountaine, and cau≈øe of all cau≈øes: who is circum≈øcribed Governed, and limited by no rules; doth all meerely, and onely by his Soveraign, and unlimited good plea≈øure, who made the world, and all things therein for his owne glory; and who by his owne will and plea≈øure, gave man (his meere creature) the Soveraignty under him≈øelfe, over all the re≈øt of the Creatures, Gen. 1.26, 28, 29. and indued him with a rationall under≈øtanding; and thereby created him after his owne Image, Gen. 1.26, 27. and 9.6. the fir≈øt of which was Adam a male man, made out of the du≈øt or clay; out of who≈øe ≈øide was taken a Rib; which by the Soveraigne, and ab≈øolute mighty creating power of God, was made a Female or Woman, call'd EVE, which two are the earthly originall Fountain as begetters & bringers forth of all and every particular, and individuall man and woman, that ever breathed in the world ≈øince; who are and were by nature a like, and equall in Power,
Dignity, Maje≈øty, &c. none of them having by nature, any Authority, Dominion, or Maje≈øteriall Power one over or above another; neither have they, or can they execute any, but meerely by in≈øtitution, or donation, that is to ≈øay, by mutuall agreement or con≈øent given, derived, or a≈ø≈øumed, by mutuall con≈øent, and agreement, for the good, benefit, and comfort each of other; and not for the mi≈øchiefe, hurt, or dammage of any, it being unnaturall, Irationall, ≈øinfull, wicked, and unju≈øt, for any man or men what≈øoever, to part with ≈øo much of their Power, as ≈øhall unable any of their ‚òû Parliament men, Tru≈øtees, Deputies, Viceroyes, Mini≈øters, Officers, or Servants, to de≈øtroy, and undoe them therewith and al≈øo, unnaturall, unju≈øt, ≈øinfull, and divelli≈øh is it for any man what≈øoever, ≈øpirituall, temporall, Cleargy man, or lay man, to appropriate, and a≈ø≈øume unto him≈øelfe power, Authority, and Juri≈ødiction, to Rule, Governe, or Reigne over, any ≈øort of men in the world, without their free con≈øent; and who≈øoever doth it, whether Cleargie men, or any other what≈øoever, doe thereby as much as in them lyes, endeavour to appropriate and a≈ø≈øume unto them≈øelves, the Office and Soveraignty of God, who alone doth, & is to rule by his will and plea≈øure; and to be like their Creator, which was the ≈øinne of the devils, who not being content, with their fir≈øt Station, but would be like God, for which ≈øinne they were throwne downe into hell, re≈øerved in everla≈øting chaines unto the judgement of the great day, Lude v. 6. and Adams ≈øinne it was, which brought the cur≈øe upon him, and all his Po≈øterity, that he was not content in the Station, and condition, which God had created him, but did a≈øpire to a better, and more excellent, namely to be like the Creator; which proved his ruine; yea, and indeed, had been the everla≈øting ruine, and de≈øtruction of all his, &c.

div.p: Let the wi≈øe and under≈øtanding Reader, judge the Authors intention, in framing the Pro≈øcript afore recited, whether or no his inclination ≈øerveth not, were the reines in his hand, to di≈ø≈øolve the whole Frame of Government, to ≈øet up confu≈øion, and give licence to every evill worke, to be acted without controule; and yet ≈øuch was his boldne≈ø≈øe, that a the taile of his Pro≈øcript he addeth his name, as glorying in his Lines.

Oh Ma≈øter Lilburne, if e're the≈øe lines come to your vew, peru≈øe them with patience, and con≈øider what a ra≈øh and unadvi≈øed cour≈øe you have taken; having been another ACHAN, a troubler of I≈ørael; I remember what I once learned at Schoole, nunquam ≈øera e≈øt, ad benos mores via, now at length recollect your ≈øelve, ≈øet forth your recantation for the pa≈øt, and your re≈øolution for the future; which will for the glory of God, and the comfort of his Church.

But if this ≈øhall be hid from your eyes, and the ≈øpirit of delu≈øion have tane ≈øo ≈øure po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion on you; all I can doe, is to deplore your mi≈øerable condition, and to pray God to open the eyes of your minde, that you may ≈øee, in what a Labyrinth of evils you are involved; as al≈øo this Ile wherein we live by your meanes, and tho≈øe bearing as evill a minde as your ≈øelfe: was ever a Nation ≈øo mi≈øerably divided, and according, as one of our Modern Poets ≈øaid truly, in a Poem of his lately Printed.

lg.l: Some for the Parliament partake,
Some for the King a party make,
As he is King, and ≈øome that hee
A Tyrant might become to be.
Some would aWhere the people ruled. popular E≈øtate;
SomeArbitrary Government. Ari≈øtocracie Create;
Some are a Faction for the Pope,
Some to maintaine the Prelats hope;
Some for the Pre≈øbiterians Vote,
Some Independencie promote;
Some ≈øtrive for this, and ≈øome for that;
Some neither know, nor care for what,
So warres goe on, and get they may
Free Quarter, Plunder, and their Pay;
Some fight their liberties to ≈øave,
Some that they others might en≈ølave;
Some for Religion, and for Chri≈øt,
Some that they might doe what they li≈øt;
Some for the Common-wealth availe,
Some for them≈øelves, with Tooth and Naile;
And they that have the ba≈øe≈øt end,
As fairly as the be≈øt pretend.
"This is our Po≈øture, and whil'≈øt we,
"So fooli≈øh fal≈øe, and factious be;
"Or while affaires continue thus,
"Who knowes what will become of us?

div.p:
I have read in the Chronicles of a Speech of King HENRY the Eight, to the French Emba≈ø≈øadour, now being in hand with that glorious worke of aboli≈øhing the Popes power‚ñ™ If your Ma≈øter (≈øaid he) will be ruled by me, we will not leave Ma≈ø≈øe in all our Kingdomes. O that God would put it into the hearts of our Rulers and Governours, not to leave one Here≈øie in the Kingdome unabolli≈øhed; the ≈ømalle≈øt capacities may conceive, and the blinde≈øt eye may di≈øcerne, that if they be not taken away, it will cau≈øe God to take away his Go≈øpell from us, and prove the inevitable ruine, and de≈øtruction of this Nation, which hath till of late yeeres been renowned through the earth, for peace and plenty; and peculiarly ble≈ø≈øed, in having the Go≈øpell ≈øincerely preached, voyd of Faction and Schi≈øme. But I hope the honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament will ere long, ayded by him, who hath hitherto ayded them in a wonderfull manner, wipe away and leave no blemi≈øh of this great ≈øpot, and manife≈øt ≈øtaine to our Nation; in the mean time it were to be wi≈øhed, that the Framers, Printers, and Divulgers, of Slanders, Here≈øies, and lies, were by ≈øome ≈øtrict cour≈øe prohibited from their frequent and cu≈øtomary u≈øe of ≈øpreading abroad bookes and Pamphlets, the contents whereof tend to the di≈øhonour of God, the breach of peace, and the infecting and ≈øeducement of the people, apt enough of them≈øelves in this wavering age, to fall into errours without a prompter. I know this will be taken in evill part by ≈øome, but let them know, what a great man of this Realm once ≈øaid to one, that de≈øired him to be a meanes of calling in a booke, ≈øharpely but truely rebuking the deeds of ≈øome notorious
offenders, that it was fit THAT THOSE THAT DID WHAT THEY SHOULD NOT, SHOULD HEARE WHAT THE WOULD NOT.

Was there ever a pre≈øident ≈øince the worlds foundation as this, that God, and his Chri≈øt, and his holy word, ≈øhould be ≈øo bla≈øphemed and evill ≈øpoken of; the King, the Commons, and all ≈øorts of men ≈øo abu≈øed, and railed on: as now they are by Paul Be≈øt, and John Lilburne! the one denying the di≈øtinction of the Trinity; the other averring, there ought to be no ≈øubjection to any. And here I cannot but wonder at the wilfull blindne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe men, who will not be convinced of their error, and in particularly Mr Lilburne, who again≈øt the cleare light of nature, ob≈øtinately affirmeth his impri≈øonment is unju≈øt and illegall, and ≈øeemeth to wonder at his u≈øage, as in his booke, entituled, THE FREE-MANS FREEDOM VINDICATED, p. 7. where relating the manner of his owne apprehending, and being brought before the Lords he hath this pa≈ø≈øage, My u≈øage to me ≈øeems ≈øtrange, for doing my duty in a ju≈øt way, &c.

Why ≈øhould it ≈øeeme ≈øtrange to any man (if putting his finger in the fire, it be burnt?) or why ≈øhould it be a wonder to Ma≈øter Lilburne, if that for his fal≈øe accu≈øations, and rebellious proceedings, he be called to an account, and ≈øuffer for unju≈øt, and unholy actions; All Hi≈øtories, both Morrall and Divine, relate that divers, for le≈ø≈øe crimes then his, have undergone the rigour of the Law,In 88 Penree tooke the ≈øame way to ≈øtir up ≈øedition, as you doe now. and ≈øuffered death: as Penree in daies of Queen ELIZABETH; and to my knowledge, it is the feare of his be≈øt Friends, that his end will be violent, who per≈øi≈øteth without remor≈øe from ill to ill, and placeth his Felicity in ca≈øting calumnies and a≈øper≈øions on the innocent: as on my ≈øelfe, who never wronged him in my life, any way, either by word or deed.

Did Mr Lilburne con≈øider what a capitall crime it is before God‚ñ™ to cen≈øure the innocent, he would be more wary what he penned or publi≈øhed; and it will be ≈øurely a blemi≈øh to the many pious actions of tho≈øe who mought, but were remi≈ø≈øe to prohibit it. It therefore behooveth every man the lea≈øt vertuous, to pray unto the Lord God, that he will put into the hearts of the ever honoured Lords and Commons to remedy this evill.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p: THus not out of any malice, or former grudge, I take God to witne≈ø≈øe, have I wrote this ≈ømall Tract, but onely to vindicate my ≈øelfe, ≈øo gro≈ø≈øely and manife≈øtly abu≈øed by Mr Lilburne. And here perhaps ≈øome man may ≈øay (and that truely) that I needed not to have troubled my ≈øelfe, to have put forth an an≈øwer, all men knowing his lying humour, and his frequent ≈ølanders are ≈øuch, that all wi≈øemen count the party ≈øo much the more vertuous, by how much the more he is calumniated by him; but let him be plea≈øed to con≈øider, that although his cau≈øe would have been ≈øo, and no otherwi≈øe looked upon by the truely judicious, yet the vulgar are apt, on the lea≈øt in≈øtigation, to apprehend the lea≈øt accu≈øation tending to the defaming of any in Office, not looking on the cau≈øe of his accu≈øation, nor the wickedne≈ø≈øe of the party,Who hath adventured his life for the Parliament at Mar≈øton more, and was to be pulled out of the Hou≈øe when the King came for the five members. his accu≈øer. As for in≈øtance, how hath his lies taken impre≈ø≈øion, and eate as a Canker into the honour of the right Noble the Earle of Manche≈øter, Col. King. &c. Therefore if tho≈øe potent and honourable per≈øons, could not ≈øhake him off without ≈øome dammage, what could I have looked for, if I had ≈øate ≈øtill, and not an≈øwered his fal≈øe accu≈øation.

And here I cannot but take notice of one pa≈ø≈øage, which Ma≈øter Lilburne hath in a Letter annexed to his Treati≈øe, as if penned by ≈øome other man, entituled, An excellent Letter, written by a pri≈øoner to a worthy member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, his words are the≈øe: O where is Ju≈øtice? may not tho≈øe Royall plunderers as well ju≈øtifie all the Hou≈øe of Peeres, the≈øe impri≈øonments and commitments. Let the Reader reading this, admire at the unheard of impudence of this man, who ≈øticketh not to compare the Acts of the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament to be as illegall, and unju≈øt, ≈øinfull
and execrable, as the wor≈øt of the Royall party. Marke how this man maketh the Word of God his rule, who commandeth not to ≈øpeake evill of Dignities, muchle≈ø≈øe to affront and vilifie them fal≈øely, and on no ground ≈øave malice; and when they are taxed, or ≈øuffer the lea≈øt for their exorbitancies, cry out, Magna Charta is broken, and unheard of cruelties are u≈øed, the ≈øubject is en≈ølaved, and brought into Egyptian bondage. And yet the≈øe men, and in particular Mr Lilburne would make the world believe, that this is the way that he Word of God alloweth, which if it be, as every good man will acknowledge: how comes it to pa≈ø≈øe that he and his complices tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe therefrom,He lieth at home every Sabbath if never ≈øo good a man do preach. venting their own corrupt doctrine in Hou≈øes, and ob≈øcure places, contrary to the example of our Saviour, who delivered nothing in ≈øecret, ≈øave tho≈øe things which he had him≈øelfe ordained the Jewes for their wickedne≈ø≈øe ≈øhould not participate of, and that ≈øo the Scriptures might be fulfilled; but el≈øe how often is it ≈øaid, And he ≈øate down in the midde≈øt of the people and taught them? not in hou≈øes and corners. For my owne part, in tempory affaires, and as concerning the execution of my duty, wherein I am intru≈øted; I dare any man Religious, to utter the wor≈øt he can of me; and for Mr Lilburne, he in ≈øtandering me hath not detracted from my reputation, but ≈øinned again≈øt him≈øelfe.
